title: The Destination Homepage
content:
You can reinvest in the homepage as a destination, trying to inspire people to type your URL into their browser. […] You can make the homepage feel nice and valuable, unique to the brand or function of your enterprise, the way opening your Twitter feed once felt valuable.

– Kyle Chayka: The Internet's distribution problem (2024)

Describing the homepage as a destination carries within it the idea of travel, of moving through the digital as one moves through physical space. This opposes the notion of the digital as an entirely personal thing, enveloping and conforming to individual preferences. Thinking of the homepage as a destination, as a place, means understanding that it is shared with other visitors. It means understanding the each website has to find balance between its visitor's interests. This is an uniquely architectural problem.

Furthermore, visiting places implies active intent on the part of the visitor: leaving our space to visit a destination is something we have to be motivated, ideally enthusiastic about – as opposed to expectating the universe to render its servives to us, magically conforming to our desires, without intent, movement, motivation or enthusiasm on our part.

Visiting a destination homepage is the tinyest way of Opposing Convenience, a modicum of curiosity for the Herzogian virtue of travel on foot in the digital space that is the world wide web.
